variant.question:
The FMS navigation data base usually contains 
1 airport reference data
2 ATC frequencies
3 Company routes.
4 NavAid frequencies
 The combination regrouping all the correct statements is

options.text: 1 and 3.

variant.question: A flight control system is fail-operational if, in the event of a failure

options.text: the approach, flare and landing can be completed automatically.
the approach only can be completed automatically.
there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude but the landing is not completed automatically.
the landing is not completed automatically.

variant.question: When the autopilot is coupled to the normal LNAV mode, the FMS computes...

options.text: the great circle track between the waypoints, by using VOR, DME, GNSS and IRS input.
the optimum vertical flight path, based on fuel consumption and cost index.
altitude restrictions of the airspaces and altitude requirements for crossing waypoints.
the lateral flight path, based on the aircraft's performance database.

variant.question: During the final approach, ILS and FD show contradicting information. The pilot flying should...

options.text: follow the ILS and ignore the FD.
follow the PAPI.
declare an emergency.
follow the FD and ignore the ILS.

variant.question: What should the pilot do in case of information mismatch between the ILS and FD on final approach?

options.text: Follow the ILS and ignore FD.
Follow the FD and ignore ILS.
Continue normally.
Follow the PAPIS.

variant.question: On a modern commercial aircraft, the FMS provides:

options.text: lateral and vertical navigation, and guidance and performance management.
traffic alert information
an air ground/data link.
a 3D area navigation and an air/ground datalink.

variant.question: When selecting navaids to auto-tune in order to update position, the FMS selects:

options.text: The optimum navaids in terms of signal strength and geometry.
The closest navaids.
Only those navaids in the active flight plan.
The optimum navaids along track and back-course.

variant.question: After an approach at your destination, the weather is found to be below limits, and you decide to divert to your alternate aerodrome. During initial climb you notice that the leading-edge devices are not completely retracted. After completing all necessary actions to deal with this abnormal condition, you check the FMS for ETA and fuel remaining at the diversion aerodrome. Based on the above, you can...

options.text: use the FMS time predictions, but you can NOT use the fuel predictions.
use both the FMS time and fuel predictions.
NOT use the FMS time predictions, but you can use the FMS fuel predictions.
NOT use any of the FMS time or fuel predictions.

variant.question: RNP1 (Required Navigation Performance) requires a navigation performance of plus or minus...

options.text: 1 NM both lateral and longitudinal 95% of the flying time
1 NM lateral 95% and longitudinal 90% of the flying time
2 NM lateral 95% and longitudinal 90% of the flying time
1 NM lateral 90% and longitudinal 95% of the flying time

variant.question:
The FMS FLIGHT PLAN, PROGRESS or LEG page generally displays the following parameters relative to the flight plan legs or waypoints:
1) distance.
2) time prediction.
3) waypoint elevation.
4) track.
The combination which re-groups all of the correct statements is:

The FMS FLIGHT PLAN, PROGRESS or LEG page generally displays the following parameters relative to the flight plan legs or waypoints:
1) FMS position.
2) time prediction.
3) track.
4) distance.
The combination which re-groups all of the correct statements is:

The FMS FLIGHT PLAN or LEG page displays the following parameters relative to the flight plan legs or waypoints:

1 – distance2 – altitude constraint or prediction3 – waypoint elevation4 – track
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
By which method are RNAV waypoints usually inserted into an aircraft’s FMS by the pilot?

options.text: Automatically loaded into the FMS using a company route registration/airport pairing from the navigation database.
Manually by inserting one waypoint at a time, during the flight.
Automatically sent from the pilot’s electronic flight bag (EFB) to the FMS.
Manually by selecting the CRS/DISTANCE on an HSI.

variant.question: Concerning the FMS, entering a cost index of zero results in:

options.text: maximum range airspeed.
minimum airspeed.
maximum cruising airspeed.
minimum range airspeed.

variant.question:
For most FMS the fuel prediction function, which computes the remaining fuel along the flight plan, takes into account the following situations:
1. the gross weight if the aircraft
2. the current wind computed or the resulting ground speed
3. the additional drag in case the landing gear remains extended
4. the additional drag resulting in a missing fuselage or wing element in compliance with the CDL (Configuration Deviation List)
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
An aircraft loses its GPS signal, what effect could this have with the FMS?

options.text: It will use the IRS position
none as it uses radio aids for position, not GPS
no effect
the aircraft position could be different from what is calculated

variant.question: Sources of navigation data outputs of the FMC that are displayed on an EFIS are..

options.text: navigation radios, GPS, and IRS.
GPS, AWR, and navigation radios.
IRS, navigation radios, and TCAS.
IRS, AWR, and navigation radios.

variant.question: The number included in the RNP Specification (e.g. RNP 5) describes the required:

options.text: Lateral and longitudinal accuracy in NM (at 95% of flight time).
Vertical accuracy in hundreds of feet (at 95% of flight time).
Lateral accuracy in NM (at 63% of flight time).
Number of active RNAV systems (at 63% of flight time).

variant.question:
The FMS (Flight Management System) navigation database typically includes the following data:
1) airport reference data.
2) ATC frequencies.
3) company routes.
4) nav aid frequencies.
The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:

The FMS (Flight Management System) navigation database typically includes the following data:
1) SIDs and STARs.
2) radio aids.
3) optimum flight level.
4) company routes.
5) cruise speeds.
The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:

The FMS (Flight Management System) navigation database typically includes the following data:
1) obstacles.
2) navaids.
3) SID, STAR and approaches procedures.
4) waypoints.
5) airways.
The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:
For which non-standard configuration can an FMS normally compute the fuel prediction?

options.text: One engine inoperative.
Flaps/slats not retracted.
Flaps/slats not retracted and gear down.
One engine inoperative and speed brakes deployed.

variant.question: What will happen if the GPS position inputs to the FMS are reduced?

options.text: Position computation is less accurate and RNAV approaches are not available anymore.
The FMS will become inoperative but the RNAV approaches will still be available.
The aircraft might experience position computation problems and potentially a map shift on the ND.
The FMS will become inoperative.

variant.question: The FMS navigation database processing should include the following check(s):

options.text: at each phase of the process, from the reception of each supplier's data to the distribution and loading of the formatted database.
at the loading phase into the FMS, the check is performed by the FMS.
at the end of the FMS formatting phase of all of the data collected and assembled.
at the reception of each supplier's data and after the assembly of those data collected.

variant.question: Kalman filtering is used within:

options.text: a flight management system (FMS).
a VOR receiver.
an electronic flight instrument system (EFIS).
a DME receiver.

variant.question: The FMS can automatically tune radio navigation facilities in its database. Its choice is based on the:

options.text: suitability of the available signal in terms of geometry and strength.
performance factor in the aircraft database.
frequency of the radio aid, choosing the highest.
proximity of the radio facility.

variant.question: A FMS with only a multiple DME sensor operating shall have a position error, 95% probability, in a non-precision approach equal or less than:

options.text: 0.3 NM
1 NM
0.5 NM

variant.question:
The FMS navigation database includes the following data:
1. airports
2. take off speeds
3. navaids
4. terrain
5. runways
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
Typical position inputs to an FMS are...

options.text: GPS, IRS ,VOR, DME, LOC
IRS,VOR, NDB, ADF, LOC
GPS, IRS ,VOR, DME, NDB, LOC
GPS, IRS ,VOR, NDB, ADF

variant.question: Due to a drive failure, the slats of a transport category aircraft do not retract properly after take-off. How will this impact the FMS in terms of ETA and fuel predictions?

options.text: ETA will be calculated accurately but fuel prediction will no longer be accurate.
ETA and fuel prediction will no longer be accurate.
ETA will no longer be accurate, and fuel prediction will be accurately calculated.
ETA or fuel prediction indications remain reliable.

variant.question: Can GPS position be supplied to FMS?

options.text: Yes, it’s one of the primary position information sources.
No, only IRS or INS position information is used.
No, GPS position is not accurate enough.
Yes, but only if the signal is calibrated with caution.

variant.question: Which of the following navaid combinations gives the most accurate (terrestrial) radio fix for updating the FMS?

options.text: DME / DME
VOR / VOR
VOR / DME
TACAN / DME

variant.question: Prior to the flight the initial fuel was inserted into the FMS. After refuelling, the FMS a fuel was indicated as being wrong. What could be the consequences?

options.text: The flight crew need to investigate the cause of the discrepancy as this might hide a fuel system failure or a leak.
FMS will issue a warning.
FMS needs to be reinitialized to give correct calculations.
The discrepancy might go undetected.

variant.question:
The FMS navigation database includes the following data:
1) obstacles.
2) waypoints.
3) SID, STAR.
4) terrain cells.
5) magnetic variation.
The combination which regroups all of the correct statements is:

The FMS is approved to provide guidance for the following approaches:
 
1. RNAV
2. ILS
3. MLS
4. VOR, NDB
 
The combination which regroups all of the correct statements is:

A FMS can correct its fuel computations for the following non-standard configurations:1 – landing gear down.  
2 – speed brakes extended.  
3 – one engine out.  
4 – slats / flaps not fully retracted.The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
The period of validity of an FMS database is:

options.text: 28 days.
varies depending on the area of operational cover.
one week.
56 days.

variant.question:
Which of the following are stored in the FMS navigation database?
1. Airport reference data
2. ATC frequencies
3. Company routes
4. NAVAID frequencies

options.text: 1, 3 and 4
1, 2 and 4
1 and 3 only
1 and 2 only

variant.question: The Fuel management performed by most FMS along the flight plan is considered as:

options.text: a function which helps the crew to estimate the remaining fuel quantity along the flight plan but should not be considered as an accurate and reliable source.
an accurate function which can be considered as the prime mean to determine the remaining fuel quantity along the flight plan.
the prime mean to manage the fuel consumption along the flight.
an accurate and very reliable function providing that the fuel on board quantity has been properly initialized by the crew before start up.

variant.question:
What are the inputs to the FMS?
1) Radio aids.
2) Engine parameters.
3) Air data.
4) Route data.
5) Terminal data.6) Operating data.
The concept of RNP applies...

options.text: to navigation performance within an airspace.
to navigation performance within an airspace using satellite navigation systems only.
to navigation performance on RNAV routes only.
to navigation performance within an airspace and a specific time-interval.

variant.question:
The FMS navigation database includes the following data

1 – airports2 – obstacles3 – navaids4 – airways5 – terrain.
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
The navigational database of Flight Management Systems (FMS):

options.text: contain additional space so that crew members can add their own waypoints.
can be modified by the crew so that navigation aids, airways and waypoints may be deleted.
is updated via datalink on a permanent basis to contain actual NOTAMs.
need to be updated by the cockpit crew as soon as the performance database is updated.

variant.question: Some FMS have an autotuning function. Which parameters can be automatically tuned?

options.text: Radio navigation frequencies.
VHF communication frequencies.
VHF communication and navigation frequencies.
HF frequencies.

variant.question: The position shown on FMS is:

options.text: FMS position.
INS.
IRS.
ADC position.

variant.question: During a ground stop the Commander notices that the FMS position is NOT in agreement with the actual aircraft position. What is the correct procedure to rectify this error? The Commander needs to...

options.text: use the CDU to enter the correct position into the system.
contact maintenance personnel to recalibrate the system.
activate the GNSS to allow the position to be automatically corrected
note the difference and manually correct calculations for the rest of the flight.

variant.question:
For most FMS the Fuel prediction function, which computes the remaining fuel along the flight plan, takes into account the following situations:
1) the additional drag resulting in a flight carried out with the landing gear extended.
2) the additional drag resulting in a flight carried out with one engine inoperative.
3) the additional drag resulting in a flight carried out with the flaps stuck partly extended.
4) the current wind computed or the resulting ground speed.
The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:
When initial position is put into an FMS, the system

options.text: rejects initial latitude or longitude error.
rejects initial longitude error, but it will accept latitude error.
cannot detect input errors, and accepts whatever is put in.
rejects initial latitude error, but it will accept longitude error.

variant.question: The Required Navigation Performance (RNP) is based on:

options.text: the horizontal position accuracy to be achieved within an airspace.
the accuracy of commercially available Inertial Navigation Systems.
the number of satellites available to perform RAIM.
the number of available flight levels within the airspace.

variant.question: The FMS autotune function can automatically tune frequencies for:

options.text: VOR and DME
Navaids, VHF and HF Comms
VHF Comms only
Navaids and VHF Comms

variant.question: The FMS Required Time of Arrival (RTA) function can provide:

options.text: a speed target to satisfy a time constraint entered at a flight plan waypoint.
a time prediction at the active TO waypoint complying with the wind computation.
a time slot computed for the arrival time at destination, using the current aircraft speed and speed constraints along the flight plan.
a time prediction at the flight plan waypoints based on the current speed and speed constraints along the flight plan.

variant.question: The pilot wants to use the FMS to fly an RNAV approach, but gets the message: ‘’NO RAIM’’. The pilot also detects that the ground course and ground speed data reported by the IRS are invalid. The pilot...

options.text: must fly the approach using raw data from ground-based navigation aids (e.g, ILS).
must use the ground speed information from the GPS and calculate the approach path by means of performance tables in the Flight Manual.
can still use the FMS to fly the RNAV approach, RAIM is only applicable to GPS approaches.
can still use the FMS to fly the RNAV approach, RAIM is only applicable to GPS approaches and ground track and speed information is NOT needed for an RNAV approach.

variant.question: FMS calculations are based on...

options.text: the FMS position.
VOR/DME data.
a GNSS position.
the IRS/INS position.

variant.question: For which unusual aircraft configuration can the FMC calculate the fuel requirements?

options.text: One engine inoperative
Speed brakes stuck and one engine inoperative
Landing gear down, and slats/flaps not retracted
Slats/flaps not retracted

variant.question: Some Flight Management Systems have dedicated navigation receivers (for example, DME) allowing for the automatic tune function. The main advantage of the automatic tuning is that...

options.text: it provides the best available signals for position calculation.
the calculated position is more correct than with manual selection.
tuning is also possible outside the Designated Operational Coverage (DOC).
tuning occurs much quicker than with manual selection.

variant.question:
The FMS (Flight Management System) navigation database typically includes the following data:
1) waypoints.
2) details of radio navigation aids.
3) optimum altitudes.
4) company routes.
5) landing reference speeds.
The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:
When the FMS is operating in 'dual mode', data is supplied to the:

options.text: Autopilot, Flight Director, Autothrottle/thrust
First officer's instruments
Captain's instruments
Navigation display

variant.question:
The FMS FLIGHT PLAN, PROGRESS or LEG page generally displays the following parameters relative to the flight plan legs or waypoints
1) time prediction.
2) distance.
3) magnetic variation.
4) altitude constraint or prediction.The combination re-grouping all the correct statements is
Which statement is true for aircraft equipment which operates to RNP 1 and better?

options.text: The equipment should be able to compute an estimated value of the aircraft’s position error.
The equipment should be able to compute the exact value of the aircraft’s position error.
The equipment should be able to correct for the exact value of the aircraft’s position error.
The equipment should be able to correct for an estimated value of the aircraft’s position error.

variant.question: An aircraft not equipped with EFIS has an inflight master caution. How can the pilots know what the failure is?

options.text: The pilots should check the annunciator panel of the flight warning system.
The pilots should refer to the emergency checklist.
The pilots should refer to the quick reference handbook.
It is type specific, so the pilots should check the FCOM abnormal procedures.
